niche.tagline: Help people close the gap between where they are and where they want to be

method.name: S.H.I.F.T. Method‚Ñ¢
method.fullTitle: The S.H.I.F.T. Method‚Ñ¢ for Life Coaching
method.description: A powerful 5-step transformation framework that moves clients from stuck to unstoppable. The S.H.I.F.T. Method combines positive psychology, cognitive behavioral techniques, and action-based coaching to create lasting life change.

steps.title: See the Full Picture
steps.description: Help clients see their current reality clearly ‚Äî without judgment, denial, or sugar-coating. Use the Wheel of Life and values assessments to map all dimensions.

steps.title: Highlight the Vision
steps.description: Co-create a vivid, emotionally compelling vision of their ideal life. Make it specific enough to pursue and inspiring enough to pull them forward.

steps.title: Identify the Blockers
steps.description: Surface limiting beliefs, self-sabotaging patterns, and hidden fears that keep clients stuck. Name them so they lose their power.

steps.title: Forge the Path
steps.description: Build a concrete, time-bound action plan with micro-goals, milestones, and contingency plans. Make the path so clear that motivation becomes optional.

steps.title: Transform Through Action
steps.description: Execute with accountability, celebrate progress, and iterate through setbacks. Transformation happens through doing ‚Äî not just planning.

examQuestions.question: What is the primary difference between life coaching and therapy?
options: Coaching is future-focused on goals and action; therapy addresses past wounds and clinical conditions
examQuestions.explanation: Life coaching is future-focused ‚Äî helping clients set and achieve goals through action and accountability. Therapy typically addresses past experiences, trauma, and clinical mental health conditions.

examQuestions.question: What does the 'I' in the S.H.I.F.T. Method‚Ñ¢ stand for?
examQuestions.explanation: The 'I' stands for 'Identify the Blockers' ‚Äî surfacing limiting beliefs, self-sabotaging patterns, and hidden fears that keep clients stuck.

examQuestions.question: What are 'powerful questions' in coaching?
options: Open-ended questions that provoke insight, self-reflection, and new perspectives
Questions the coach already knows the answer to
examQuestions.explanation: Powerful questions are open-ended, thought-provoking questions that help clients discover their own insights and solutions ‚Äî a core competency in professional coaching.

examQuestions.question: Why don't life coaches need to 'have all the answers'?
options: They can Google things during sessions
The coaching model relies on helping clients discover their OWN answers through questions and reflection
They do need all the answers
examQuestions.explanation: Professional coaching operates on the principle that clients are naturally creative, resourceful, and whole. The coach's role is to ask questions that unlock the client's own wisdom and solutions.

examQuestions.question: In the S.H.I.F.T. Method‚Ñ¢, why does the 'Forge' step make motivation 'optional'?
options: Because when the path is so clear and broken into micro-steps, action becomes easier than avoidance
examQuestions.explanation: When the action plan is crystal clear with specific micro-goals and milestones, the friction to act is reduced so dramatically that clients don't need to rely on motivation ‚Äî clarity drives action.

zombie.name: Keisha
zombie.backstory: High school English teacher for 12 years who realized she spent more time coaching her students through life problems than teaching grammar. Everyone in her life came to her for advice, but she had no framework for it.
zombie.transformation: After getting certified, Keisha launched a coaching practice specializing in career transitions for women in education. She uses the S.H.I.F.T. Method‚Ñ¢ with every client and now has a 3-week waitlist.
zombie.incomeStory: Keisha earns $5,400/month coaching part-time while still teaching 3 days a week. She plans to go full-time coaching next school year.
zombie.writingStyle: Energetic, motivational, uses caps for emphasis. Teacher-like clarity. Loves storytelling. Very encouraging of fellow career changers.
exampleMessages: 12 years of teaching English and what was I REALLY doing? COACHING. Every parent conference, every after-school chat ‚Äî it was all coaching. The S.H.I.F.T. Method just made it official üòç
client UPDATE: she got the promotion!! the one she told me she'd 'never' get?? We used the Identify step to crush her limiting beliefs and the Forge step to build her pitch. I AM SCREAMING
if you're a natural advice-giver who everyone comes to for 'the talk' ‚Äî you're already a coach. you just need the framework. this training IS that framework

faq.q: Do I need a psychology degree?
faq.a: No. Life coaching is a distinct profession from therapy. Many successful coaches come from education, corporate, healthcare, or completely unrelated backgrounds.
The coaching industry is growing 15% annually. The key is niching down ‚Äî our training helps you find your specific lane where demand exceeds supply.
Absolutely. Most of our graduates start with 3-5 clients while keeping their current job, then transition to full-time once they build momentum.

sarah.credentials: ICF-Aligned Life Coach Educator & Transformation Specialist
sarah.storySnippet: I developed the S.H.I.F.T. Method‚Ñ¢ after realizing that most people don't need more information ‚Äî they need someone to help them close the gap between knowing and doing. That's what coaching is.

buyerPersona.demographics: Women 30-50, many from education/corporate/healthcare backgrounds, natural 'helpers' and advice-givers
buyerPersona.psychographics: People others already come to for advice. Want to formalize what they naturally do. Seeking purpose-driven work with flexibility.
objections: Can I actually charge people to talk?
